history: Earliest known form is a single horizontal stroke representing the number one or a single entity in counting.
A vertical stroke that often signifies a pole or line, used as a fundamental stroke in Chinese calligraphy.
A single dot stroke, historically used as a mark or small point for emphasis or annotation.
A slanted stroke that can represent a slash or an oblique line, often seen in early pictographic forms.
Originally depicted as a curved shape symbolizing a bent object, later used to denote 'second' in enumerations.
A hook-shaped stroke derived from more complex graphs, signifying a hooking or pulling action in writing.
Two horizontal strokes representing the number two, an extension from the single line for one.
Often described as a 'lid' or 'top' radical; its ancient form resembled a small cover or roof shape.
A pictograph of a standing person, with two legs slightly apart, denoting humanity or an individual.
Depicts a person with legs extended, sometimes interpreted as a child or the lower limbs of a person.
Originally a pictograph of two lines converging, symbolizing entering or going into an opening.
Depicts an open shape, sometimes interpreted as 'to divide' or 'eight' due to two diverging strokes.
A down box shape resembling a wide-open enclosure, historically used to indicate a border or open country.
A covering radical that symbolizes a wrap or cover, possibly derived from the shape of a cloth overhead.
A two-stroke form indicating ice or cold, derived from drawings showing frozen water droplets.
Originally a small table or stool shape, representing a piece of furniture with legs.
An open box shape, possibly a container or receptacle viewed from above.
A pictograph of a knife or blade, with the handle and blade clearly represented in early scripts.
Depicts a muscular arm or a plow shape, symbolizing physical strength or power in ancient forms.
Represents a wrapping or embracing shape, possibly depicting arms wrapped around something.
A pictograph of a spoon or ladle, though sometimes interpreted as a dagger in certain contexts.
A right-facing open box, indicating a container or enclosure open on one side.
A hiding enclosure or box with a cover, signifying a confined space or hidden area.
A cross shape signifying the number ten, also viewed as a plus sign in modern interpretation.
Originally represented a crack or line used in divination on oracle bones, meaning to divine or prophesy.
A seal or kneeling person shape in ancient scripts, representing a sign of authority or official seal.
A cliff or overhang shape, resembling the side of a steep cliff.
A private enclosure or an elbowed shape, often associated with secrecy or privacy.
Depicts a hand (often the right hand) in ancient forms; also carries the sense of 'again.'
A square shape representing a mouth or an opening in pictographic origins.
A large enclosure or border, often used as a radical indicating surrounding or containing.
Pictograph of a clump of soil or earth, with a horizontal line indicating the ground.
Originally denoted a gentleman or scholar, combining the shape of 'earth' with an extra stroke to signify status.
A walking or trailing foot shape in ancient forms, indicating movement or following.
Similar to 夂, but with strokes rearranged, suggesting walking slowly or dragging the feet.
A crescent moon shape, representing evening or night.
Depicts a person with arms and legs spread, symbolizing something big or great.
A pictograph of a woman kneeling or seated, representing femininity.
A child wrapped in swaddling clothes, depicted with a larger head and small body.
Represents a roof or house top, used to indicate shelter or a covered structure.
A symbol of measurement (about an inch), possibly showing a hand with the thumb extended.
Three small strokes signifying 'small' or 'little.'
Depicts a person with a bent leg or walking stick, meaning 'lame' or 'weak.'
A corpse or body lying down, originally depicting a person leaning over or deceased.
A sprout pushing through the ground, representing new growth or young plants.
A pictograph of three mountain peaks, signifying a mountain range or hill.
Three vertical lines representing a flowing river or stream.
Depicts a carpenter’s square or tool, indicating work or construction.
A pictograph of a twisted rope or self-coiling form, later associated with 'oneself.'
Shows a cloth or towel hanging down, used to represent cloth-related concepts.
Originally a pictograph of a shield or a stem, meaning 'to interfere' or 'dry' depending on context.
Depicts a small, tiny silk thread or something slight and delicate.
Shows a wide house or shelter open on one side, signifying a large space or building.
A stride or long step, depicted as a person taking an elongated stride.
Represents two hands joined or holding something together, indicating a combined effort.
An arrow with a trailing rope, used for hunting birds or small game.
A bow shape, clearly illustrating the curved bow used in archery.
Also written as 彑, depicting a pig’s snout or a snout-like shape in ancient scripts.
Three wavy lines representing hair or bristles.
A 'step' radical, showing small steps or movement to the left.
A stylized heart shape, originally a pictograph of the physical heart organ.
An ancient weapon resembling a halberd or spear with a hooked blade.
A single-panel door or household entrance as viewed from the side.
A pictograph of a hand with fingers extended, representing manual actions.
A branch or support, possibly showing a hand holding a branch.
Also written as 攵, a hand holding a stick, indicating actions like hitting or tapping.
Symbolizes writing or script, originally a figure with markings on the chest indicating pattern or text.
A dipper or measuring cup, used for measuring grain in ancient China.
A type of axe or 'catty' (a unit of weight), originally showing a blade.
A square or direction, derived from a shape indicating corners or orientation.
Meaning 'not' or 'without,' sometimes seen as a person dancing with outstretched arms in ancient forms.
A circle (or rectangle) with a line inside, representing the sun with a central spot or axis.
Similar to 日 but slightly wider, meaning 'to say' or indicating speech in some contexts.
A crescent moon shape, often depicted in its waxing or waning phase.
A pictograph of a tree with branches extending upward and roots at the base.
A person yawning or breathing, indicating 'lack' or 'to owe' in extended meanings.
A foot or a representation of a foot, meaning 'to stop' or 'foot' in certain contexts.
A skeleton or decaying bones, signifying death, decay, or 'bad' things.
A hand holding a weapon or club, illustrating a tool for striking.
A female figure with emphasized breasts, representing 'mother' or female parent.
Two figures side by side, indicating comparison or parallelism.
Fur or hair, originally showing strands or bristles.
A clan or family name indicator, possibly derived from a sign or banner.
Steam or vapor rising, illustrating the concept of 'air' or 'spirit.'
Flowing water with branching streams, representing rivers or water sources.
Flames or fire, often shown with sparks in oracle bone script.
A claw or talon, depicting an animal’s paw with extended nails.
A hand holding a stick, symbolic of paternal authority or a father figure.
The crossing lines used in I Ching trigrams, indicating divination lines or changing states.
Half of a split log, indicating a board or plank of wood.
A slice or split piece of wood, symbolizing a fragment or thin piece.
An animal tooth or tusk, depicting its pointed shape.
A cow’s head with horns, representing cattle or oxen.
A variant of the 'dog' radical (犬), depicting an animal with four legs and a tail (often used as a side form).
Means 'deep' or 'mysterious,' showing something subtle and profound (often depicted as dark threads).
A pictograph of a string of jade beads, sometimes with a dot to distinguish from 王 (king).
A melon or gourd shape, with vines or tendrils in early inscriptions.
A curved roof tile shape, used for roofing in ancient China.
A pictograph of a mouth tasting sweetness, representing 'sweet.'
A sprout emerging from the ground, symbolizing birth or life.
A pictograph of a container or ladle in use, later generalized to 'to use.'
Four fields separated by lines, representing farmland or a cultivated field.
Originally depicted a foot or a bolt of cloth; it can mean 'piece' or 'roll.'
A sick person lying in bed, indicating illness or disease.
Footsteps or a person with feet apart, sometimes associated with outspread legs or movement.
A sun-like shape or a drop of whiteness, symbolizing 'white' or purity.
An animal hide stretched out, signifying 'skin' or 'hide.'
A dish or shallow container seen from above.
A pictograph of an eye with a pupil in the center.
A spear with a pointed tip, used as a weapon in ancient times.
An arrow with fletching at one end, representing archery tools.
A stone or rock, sometimes shown as a small boulder in ancient scripts.
An altar with offerings, symbolizing worship or spirit (the variant 礻 appears in compound characters).
A track or footprint, sometimes indicating traces or paw prints.
A grain plant (like rice) with drooping stalks, representing cereal crops.
A cave or hole with a small opening, indicating a dwelling or pit.
A person standing upright, symbolizing 'to stand' or 'to establish.'
Two bamboo stalks with leaves, depicting the tall, hollow stems of the bamboo plant.
Grains of rice scattered, representing uncooked rice.
A variant form of 糸 (silk), showing threads twisted together in its simplified form.
An earthenware jar or pot, often depicted with a wide body and narrow neck.
A net or web shape, originally drawn with crossing lines (罒 is another variant).
A ram’s head with horns, representing sheep or goat.
Two wings or feathers side by side, symbolizing plumage or flight.
An old man with a bent back and walking stick, indicating old age or venerable status.
Represents a beard or jaw area, sometimes indicating 'and' or 'but' in modern usage.
A plow or farming tool, showing the handle and tines for tilling soil.
A pictograph of an ear, with the inner structure hinted at in ancient scripts.
A hand holding a brush, symbolizing writing or drawing.
A piece of meat with lines indicating muscle fibers (often looks like 月 in modern script).
An official or minister bowing, also interpreted as an eye viewed from the side in oracle bone scripts.
A nose or 'self,' originally showing a profile of the nose area, signifying oneself.
An arrow reaching its target or a concept of arriving or culminating.
A mortar for grinding grains, with a hollowed-out center.
A tongue sticking out of a mouth, representing speech or taste.
Two feet facing opposite directions, indicating 'opposition' or 'contrary.'
A boat or ship with a pointed front, used for water travel.
A symbol of the I Ching trigram for 'mountain,' also indicating 'stopping' or 'stubbornness.'
Originally showed a person and a form of sensuality or bare flesh, later meaning 'color.'
A grass or plant radical, with two horizontal strokes representing grassy growth.
Stripes of a tiger’s fur, representing the pattern on a tiger.
A snake-like creature, later generalized to insects or worms.
A vessel or container of blood, sometimes shown as a basin with a drop.
A crossroad or street intersection, depicting movement or going.
A garment with sleeves, representing clothes or covering.
A basket or container shape; in old Chinese geography it was associated with 'west.'
Originally an eye on a human figure, meaning 'to see.'
An animal horn, showing its curved shape, also used to mean angle or corner.
A simplified form of 言 (speech), depicting words or speech emanating from a mouth.
A valley with the sides sloping downward, or grains contained within.
A tall vessel or bean container, used for offerings in ancient ceremonies.
A pig with a snout and legs, representing swine in profile.
A beast-like form, often associated with wild animals such as badgers.
A cowrie shell, used as currency in ancient China, hence connotations of value and wealth.
A person with lines indicating bare flesh, hence 'red' or 'bare.'
A foot in motion, indicating 'to walk' or sometimes 'to run.'
A foot with toes, representing the concept of 'foot' or 'enough/sufficient.'
A body with a torso and limbs, sometimes interpreted as a pregnant belly in ancient scripts.
A cart or wheeled vehicle, with two wheels and an axle, simplified from 車.
A pictograph of a needle or awl, meaning 'bitter' or 'to punish' in extended senses.
A celestial symbol or a dragon shape, also tied to a time period (7-9 a.m.) in ancient China.
A road or movement radical, depicting a path with a trailing footstep.
A city or town enclosure, representing an inhabited area or district.
A wine jar or jug, relating to fermentation, alcohol, and the zodiac hour (5-7 p.m.).
A hand separating grain, meaning 'to separate' or 'distinguish.'
A village or a unit of distance, originally showing a field with earth beneath.
A simplified form of 金 (metal), representing metal or related concepts.
A person with long hair or something extended, also meaning 'leader' or 'to grow.'
A gate with two hinged doors, symbolizing an entrance or exit.
A mound or hill, sometimes signifying abundant earth or a large raised area.
A captured person or slave, also the name of the clerical script style in calligraphy.
A short-tailed bird with distinct tail feathers, often referencing small birds.
Rain falling from clouds, with drops descending from the sky.
A sprout or plant emerging, associated with the color green/blue and the notion of 'youth.'
Two wings facing opposite directions, meaning 'not' or 'wrong.'
A face in profile, showing an eye and nose, representing a surface or face.
An animal hide stretched out, symbolizing leather or transformation.
A tanned leather hide, simplified from 革 with a different orientation.
Leek plants with long leaves, bunched together.
A sound or tone; ancient forms show a person making noise or chanting under a covering.
A leaf or page, originally depicting a head (首) with an extra stroke, used for pages or heads.
Wind blowing, often depicted as a swirl with something carried by it.
A bird in flight with wings spread, meaning 'to fly.'
A simplified form of 食 (to eat), combining aspects of spoon and mouth.
A head with hair, indicating the top or beginning of something.
A stalk of grain emitting fragrance, symbolizing 'incense' or a pleasant aroma.
A horse in profile, simplified from 馬, showing head, legs, and tail.
A bone with marrow or joints indicated, referencing the skeletal structure.
A tall tower or building with multiple levels, symbolizing height.
Long hair or shaggy hair, showing strands extending downward.
A stylized depiction of two people fighting or a confrontation.
A sacrificial wine vessel with aromatic herbs, used in ancient rituals.
A tripod cauldron with three legs, used for cooking or rituals.
A ghost or spirit with a pronounced head and odd body shape, signifying apparitions or supernatural beings.
A fish with fins and tail, simplified from the traditional 魚.
A bird with wings and tail, simplified from the traditional 鳥.
Salt or brine, originally showing a pot for boiling salty water.
A deer with antlers and four legs, depicted in profile.
Wheat stalks with drooping heads, simplified from 麥.
A hemp plant, with fibers used for cloth, depicted with multiple stalks under a roof.
A representation of the color 'yellow,' possibly connected to fertile earth or flame in ancient etymology.
A millet plant with seeds, an important ancient grain.
A darkened chimney or a figure blackened by soot, indicating 'black.'
Embroidery or needlework, showing a pattern of stitches.
A frog or toad, with a large head and body, sometimes depicted in water.
A three-legged bronze cauldron, a symbol of authority and ritual in ancient China.
A drum with two drumsticks, used in ceremonies or music.
A rat or mouse with a long tail, often shown from above.
A nose with nostrils and a bridge, also part of the face radicals.
Originally 齊, showing uniform rows of people or crops, meaning 'even' or 'together.'
A row of teeth in a mouth, simplified from the older form 齒.
A dragon in a simplified form, a mythical creature with a long, scaled body.
A turtle or tortoise shell, simplified from the older form 龜.
A flute or wind instrument with multiple holes, used in ancient music and ceremonies.
